Bash("/Users/josephlawsky/Desktop/Joseph Portfolio/src/app/components/ColorSchemeCaseStudy.tsx" << 'ENDOFFILE' import { CaseStudyLayout } from './CaseStudyLayout'; import { Section } from './Section'; import { Callout } from './Callout'; import { OutcomeGrid } from './OutcomeGrid'; import { AnimatedSection } from './AnimatedSection'; export function ColorSchemeCaseStudy\(\) { return \(

Two systems, zero shared foundation

As captain of design systems for our DesignOps team, I manage two enterprise design systems — Ant Design and Material UI — supporting 260+ designers across dozens of product teams. Each system had its own color palettes, naming conventions, and styling logic. Teams entrenched in their tools had created visual inconsistency across products, and every change required manual updates in two places.

Build a shared color foundation that works across both systems without disrupting how teams already work, then create the infrastructure to maintain it at scale.

Discovery & validation

I started with a comprehensive audit of both design libraries — collecting all active hex codes, creating visual comparisons, and mapping overlap. Out of hundreds of values, only three colors were consistent: brand orange, link blue, and white.

To test feasibility, I ran a targeted experiment with those 7 shared colors. The pilot surfaced critical insights: small-scale alignment was technically feasible, but both systems handled color overrides differently, and limited palettes constrained the flexibility our large, diverse teams needed. We needed a complete redesign, not incremental fixes.

Designing for scale

Research into modern design systems revealed two approaches: minimal prescriptive systems that tightly control usage, or expansive systems providing broader choice within structure. With 260+ designers across dozens of products, we clearly needed the latter.

The architecture: 10 full-spectrum color palettes \(including neutrals and slate\), each with 10 shades from 50 to 900. Every palette anchored by a primary "500" tone, hex-matched to brand guidelines. Built-in accessibility through defined contrast ranges for light and dark variants. This gave designers choice while ensuring consistency through structure and naming.

From palette to infrastructure

The new palette was finalized. But a palette without infrastructure is just a document. Both libraries used their own internal naming schemes — changing a single color meant digging through multiple files, updating each system manually, and hoping everything matched. I initially mapped old color names to new values, which aligned colors visually but didn't solve the underlying problem.

We needed design tokens — not as a tool, but as the backbone of a maintainable system. Define a value once, reference it everywhere, update it instantly.

I designed a four-layer token system: raw hex values, reference tokens \(Slate/Slate-50\), semantic tokens \(Background-Hover\), and component tokens \(Button/Primary/Hover-Background\). Colors grouped by purpose — Brand, Text, Background, Status, Action, System. Both libraries connected to a single set of Figma Variables, with components refactored to use tokens at the appropriate level.

Outcomes

This work established the infrastructure for consistent design at enterprise scale.

Reflection

This wasn't about unifying colors — it was about building a system that supports how design teams work at scale. The pilot with 7 colors was crucial: rather than pushing a complete redesign upfront, testing the concept early surfaced constraints that let us design the right solution instead of iterating on the wrong one.

If I did this again, I'd involve engineering earlier in token architecture planning. The final system worked, but earlier collaboration would have streamlined implementation and surfaced technical considerations sooner.

Bash("/Users/josephlawsky/Desktop/Joseph Portfolio/src/app/components/DesignTokensCaseStudy.tsx" << 'ENDOFFILE' import { CaseStudyLayout } from './CaseStudyLayout'; import { Section } from './Section'; import { Callout } from './Callout'; import { OutcomeGrid } from './OutcomeGrid'; import { AnimatedSection } from './AnimatedSection'; export function DesignTokensCaseStudy\(\) { return \(

Two systems, shifting priorities

As captain of design systems, I oversee two complete third-party design systems — separate themes, libraries, and documentation for each. Teams are entrenched in their tools, and forcing a choice would create disruption without real benefit. The challenge was creating consistency across products without disrupting how teams already work.

Meanwhile, our priorities kept shifting. Asking for more resources wasn't a viable path forward.

What can we actually maintain and control that positions us for sustainable success?

Starting with what matters most

I built a universal color palette as the foundation — color is the most visible aspect of design language and affects every component, making it the natural starting point for unification. Implemented as design tokens for flexibility and scalability. Teams responded positively to having consistency without losing their tools.

After the color system proved tokens worked, I recognized the larger opportunity. Tokens give us a single source of truth we can realistically maintain. Teams can apply them to whatever system they're using. This approach works with emerging AI tools that consume design tokens. And we keep foundational consistency instead of maintaining two complete themes — freeing our engineer from full-time theme building to work on higher-value projects.

Driving the change

I expanded beyond color to comprehensive token coverage — typography, spacing, elevation, and more. Now leading alignment workshops to establish tokens as our single source of truth rather than attempting to maintain two complete themes.

This isn't about doing less. It's about focusing effort where it creates the most value. Teams maintain consistency and flexibility. We maintain something sustainable. And we're positioned for whatever tools emerge next.

Expected impact

In progress, but the path is clear.

Reflection

Strategy isn't always about having the perfect plan upfront. Sometimes the most effective approach is to start with what's immediately valuable, pay attention to what works, and recognize when the work reveals a bigger opportunity. The color system proved tokens worked. Shifting priorities revealed we needed a more sustainable approach. The emergence of AI tools consuming design tokens validated the direction.

If I did this again, I'd communicate the strategic shift earlier. While the decision was right, bringing stakeholders along sooner would have accelerated buy-in and implementation.

Bash("/Users/josephlawsky/Desktop/Joseph Portfolio/src/app/components/HowWeAICaseStudy.tsx" << 'ENDOFFILE' import { CaseStudyLayout } from './CaseStudyLayout'; import { Section } from './Section'; import { Callout } from './Callout'; import { AnimatedSection } from './AnimatedSection'; export function HowWeAICaseStudy\(\) { return \(

Siloed experimentation

AI tools were emerging across the organization — everyone experimenting, learning, building. But in isolation. Teams weren't learning from each other, which meant the same mistakes got made repeatedly, breakthroughs stayed local, and the organization couldn't accelerate collectively.

I saw an opportunity to create a space where people could share discoveries and build collective knowledge instead of everyone figuring things out alone.

Build this grassroots — consistent, valuable, and engaging enough that people kept showing up on their own.

Building momentum through consistency

I launched bi-weekly "How We AI" meetings where people demo tools, share workflows, and learn from each other's experiments. Started with just my UX team, then quickly opened to the entire org — now including product, IT, and beyond.

To make it scalable, I built infrastructure: a companion site \(using Figma AI, naturally\) to host tools, a prompt library, tips, and meeting recordings. Added forms for submissions, signups, and feedback — all feeding into a backend I could manage. The site was responsive and mobile-friendly in less time than it would have taken to build one page in SharePoint.

The grassroots method: push people to the site, recruit presenters when I hear they're doing interesting work, make regular announcements to build excitement. Show up consistently so momentum doesn't die.

What makes it work

The challenge with any grassroots initiative: people's attention is constantly pulled elsewhere. Miss one meeting, drop one ball, and momentum dies. What's kept this going:

01

Show up every two weeks, no matter what. Consistency builds trust and habit.

02

Make participation easy. Simple forms, clear structure, low barrier to entry.

03

Extend beyond meetings. The site makes content accessible when people need it, not just during sessions.

04

Keep recruiting and promoting. Active outreach to presenters, regular reminders to attendees.

Impact

After 15 sessions, clear patterns emerged showing this was changing how people work. Average 4 presentations per meeting with 60 attendees. Presentations getting more impressive over time — people started simple, now showing complex workflows.

Someone who initially dismissed Figma AI saw another person's work at a meeting, went back and built something impressive enough to present themselves.

A distinguished engineer found the site, reached out — now I'm helping craft the AI narrative for Executive Leadership Team on adoption across UX and IT.

Asked to present at a company-wide event because of visibility from the site.

Reflection

Building community isn't about perfect planning — it's about showing up consistently, removing friction, and creating value people actually want. The grassroots approach was intentional: rather than wait for official approval, I started with what I could control. That momentum attracted participants, which created visibility, which brought executive attention.

The pattern scales beyond AI. This approach can apply to any emerging technology or organizational challenge. Build the space, show up consistently, make it easy to participate — and people will engage.

Bash("/Users/josephlawsky/Desktop/Joseph Portfolio/src/app/components/TableComponentCaseStudy.tsx" << 'ENDOFFILE' import { CaseStudyLayout } from './CaseStudyLayout'; import { Section } from './Section'; import { AnimatedSection } from './AnimatedSection'; import { InsightBlock } from './InsightBlock'; import { NarrativeBreak } from './NarrativeBreak'; import { TensionPair } from './TensionPair'; import { OutcomeGrid } from './OutcomeGrid'; export function TableComponentCaseStudy\(\) { return \( {/* --- The Setup --- */}

Designer surveys revealed Figma proficiency distributed in a bell curve — the middle wasn't where we needed it to be. Meanwhile, our component libraries weren't taking advantage of newer Figma features that could make components easier to use. Tables were the worst offender: one of our most-used components, driven by data-heavy product teams, and consistently the source of the most support requests.

The existing Table component was essentially static: 5 columns, 5 rows, with only basic properties. Any real customization required detaching — exactly what a design system component should prevent. The answer to "how do I add more columns?" was always "detach it and build what you need."

{/* --- Insight 1 --- */} {/* --- Research and redesign --- */}

Finding the right constraints

I used Figma analytics to identify files with heavy table usage, then examined what designers were actually building — not what I assumed they needed. Combined with direct conversations, three strategic constraints emerged: add enough flexibility so designers wouldn't need to detach, don't overload the library with variants that slow file loading, and make customization possible without deep Figma knowledge.

{/* --- Insight 2 --- */} {/* --- Outcomes --- */}

What changed

The redesign solved the immediate problem — but the real value was in what we learned.

{/* --- Insight 3 --- */} \); } ENDOFFILE)

Bash("/Users/josephlawsky/Desktop/Joseph Portfolio/src/app/components/CurrentWork.tsx" << 'ENDOFFILE' import { CaseStudyLayout } from './CaseStudyLayout'; import { Section } from './Section'; import { AnimatedSection } from './AnimatedSection'; import { InsightBlock } from './InsightBlock'; import { NarrativeBreak } from './NarrativeBreak'; export function CurrentWork\(\) { return \( {/* --- Design Critique Tool --- */}
Functional prototype in testing

Design Critique Tool

Our AI Design Enablement team needed a way to evaluate AI-generated design work and raise quality standards across the org. The gap: no structured feedback mechanism that could work at the speed AI generates output.

I built a Figma plugin that extracts design data and an app that processes it through an AI agent for evaluation. Comments appear exactly where they address issues on the canvas, plus a comprehensive report. Like having an AI design reviewer who speaks in specifics, not generalities.

{/* --- Translation Agent --- */}
Active prototype

Design-to-AI Translation Agent

People were getting stuck using Figma Make — they could describe what they wanted in design terms but not in the technical prompts the tool needed. Wasted credits, growing frustration, declining adoption.

I built an agent that translates "design speak" into "AI speak." Users paste code snippets, describe what's wrong or what they want, and it breaks down what's happening, identifies technical aspects they might not be aware of, and generates optimized prompts. Helps people get unstuck faster while reducing unnecessary credit usage.

{/* --- Figma AI Research --- */}
Ongoing research

Figma AI Research Project

With Figma AI creating both hype and skepticism, our org needed actual data — not opinions — on where AI tools help and where they don't. I'm running a controlled experiment measuring productivity gains and time savings across different design tasks, building the evidence base for strategic adoption decisions.

Early findings: AI tools accelerate certain workflows significantly but aren't a silver bullet. The research is helping leadership set realistic expectations and invest in AI adoption strategically rather than reactively.

Bash("/Users/josephlawsky/Desktop/Joseph Portfolio/src/app/components/PropsMasterCaseStudy.tsx" << 'ENDOFFILE' import { CaseStudyLayout } from './CaseStudyLayout'; import { Section } from './Section'; import { AnimatedSection } from './AnimatedSection'; import { InsightBlock } from './InsightBlock'; import { NarrativeBreak } from './NarrativeBreak'; import { EvidenceStrip } from './EvidenceStrip'; import { OutcomeGrid } from './OutcomeGrid'; export function PropsMasterCaseStudy\(\) { return \( {/* --- The Setup --- */}

Discovery Channel's true crime series Dead Silent needed to feel like a moody art piece, not generic true crime. The catch: procedural budget, prestige creative expectations. As Props Master, I was responsible for 75-120 working props per episode block across 17+ sets spanning multiple time periods — with a 3-person art department handling everything.

Two episodes shot over 8 days. No room for error. Every prop historically accurate, every set dressed to the director's vision. Most people in this position just grind harder. I built systems instead.

{/* --- Insight 1 --- */} {/* --- How it worked --- */}

Reusable assets, strategic relationships

I built a personal "stash" of reusable assets — police department materials, period-specific items, set dressing pieces — that carried across shows. Instead of sourcing everything from scratch each episode, I maintained a library of proven elements that could be recombined and adapted. Sound familiar?

Cross-functional relationships were equally critical. I invested in connections with other department heads and our prop house, becoming the go-to thought partner for what was really happening on set. Those relationships paid back when I needed resources fast or creative compromises that still served the vision.

"You always seem to pull it off"

We needed an Appalachian Trail shelter built from scratch on an empty patch of land — day one, no pre-call to give my crew a head start. I designed a pre-fab shelter that could be assembled in under an hour and hold up through two days of shooting with actors inside. Partnered with the prop house to plan and execute. Built on time, looked authentic, held up through the shoot.

That became the running joke with directors — they kept asking for crazier things because they knew I'd find a way. But the "way" was never heroics. It was always preparation meeting opportunity.

{/* --- Insight 2 --- */} {/* --- Translation --- */}
